articles.title: What is the orientation effect?
Orientnation Effects: Global investigations
articles.description: PSA 002 meta: Investigating Object Orientation Effects beyond 19 Languages.
articles.contents: Note The data collection was finished at June 16, 2021. This website is going to be updated with the data analysis and the writings on the report.

articles.title: What is the orientation effect?
articles.contents:
Research Questions
This study investigated in which language the match advantage of object orientations (a.k.a. orientation effect) would be detected in the sentence-picture verification task.



Figure 1: Example of matching (solid lines) and mismatching (dashed lines) sentence-picture pairs.



The orientation effects have been suggested as the empirical evidence of mental simulations. Several theoretical assumptions about the mental simulations have yet been settled. To one extend, the mental simulation was the part of language processing (Barsalou 1999, 2009). To the other extend, the mental rotation mechanisms would boost the mental simulation (Chu and Kita 2008; Pouw et al. 2014).
We addressed two primary questions in our plan:
How much of the match advantage of object orientation can be obtained within different languages?
What is the correlation between the mental rotation of objects and the match advantage across different languages?
Hypothesis
If the orientation effect is a general result, in every language we would detect this effect.
We have no specific expect for the effect in some language.
Imagery scores were the measures of mental rotation. We expect the equal imagery scores across the laboratories.
“If the mental simulation shared the cognitive processing of mental rotation, the imagery scores could be the predictor as critical as the languages.”



Barsalou, Lawrence W. 1999. “Perceptual Symbol Systems.” Behavioral and Brain Sciences 22: 577–660. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0140525X99002149.


———. 2009. “Simulation, Situated Conceptualization, and Prediction.” Philos Trans R Soc Lond B Biol Sci 364: 1281–89. https://doi.org/10.1098/rstb.2008.0319.


Chu, Mingyuan, and Sotaro Kita. 2008. “Spontaneous Gestures During Mental Rotation Tasks: Insights into the Microdevelopment of the Motor Strategy.” Journal of Experimental Psychology: General 137 (4): 706–23. https://doi.org/10.1037/a0013157.


Pouw, Wim T. J. L., Jacqueline A. de Nooijer, Tamara van Gog, Rolf A. Zwaan, and Fred Paas. 2014. “Toward a More Embedded/Extended Perspective on the Cognitive Function of Gestures.” Frontiers in Psychology 5 (April). https://doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2014.00359.

articles.title: Applications for Reproduction Study
articles.description: All the scripts and materials are available at the project [OSF](https://osf.io/e428p/).
articles.contents:
OpenSesame
Both the in-site and online studies were developed in OpenSesame. Based on the original plan, every team collect data in their experimental space. After the global pandemic outbreak, the leading researchers spent months learn javascript codes that control the OpenSesame workflow on the internet browsers. The final version is the script for English participants with the tidy code. Researchers are recommended to test this version at first.
Note For some languages, there are Chinese, Hebrew, and Arabic, the text lines can not be truncated on the sketchpad. We showedg the probe sentences in PNG format.
Researchers would download the OpenSesame from their website and test the script on your own devices. If you will run the replication in the laboratory space, you can run the experiment following Sebastiaan’s steps as like he demonstrated in his youtube video:


JATOS
Researchers would register an account at MindProbe if you will collect the data from the internet. At the time this page was updated, researchers could ask the administrator for your free account. Once your account is available, you can conduct the online experiment based on the workflow guide from the OpenSesame webiste.

articles.title: Delopy the on line experiment
articles.description: Test experiment on the desktop computers and on Internet.
articles.contents:
Test the OSWeb
Before you submit the script to the JATOS server such as MindeProbe, you must test the script as this instruction. Here are our other suggestions.
Check “Make browser fullscreen” when you are testing the script. Every participant will run this study on full screen mode.
OSWeb test shows the presentations from the beginning to the end. If you want to know how the collected data saved in the file, you can upload the script to the JATOS test server.
For some yet to be addressed issue, the practice trials can not work on OSWeb as well as on the local device. To our experience, this issue influenced little on the participants’ responses.
Use JATOS
In addition to the instruction from OpenSesame website, here are our other suggestions.
Consider the circumstance you will distribute the experiment. If you will collect the data from the crowdsorucing platforms, such as Prolific, MTurk, or Sona System, you can create “General Multiple Worker” as like the instructions on OpenSesame website.
If you will assign the particular links for each of your participants, you could create “Personal Single Worker” or “Personal Multiple Worker”. See details in the JATOS manual.
If your participants will enter the study by the particular link, they have to run the study on the desktop or laptop.

articles.title: Instructions for reproduction study
articles.description: Access all the materials at the project [OSF](https://osf.io/e428p/).
articles.contents:
Replications on the registered languages
If you will replicate this study in one of the registered languages (see this page), you can directly used the scripts in the project OSF. The final version of the experimental scripts are available for any circumstance. Namely you can conduct the study in your lab space as well as distribute it through Internet. For some languages we did not collect the data through JATOS server, you have to access the material sheets and revise the experimental script for your requirement.
Replications on the unregistered languages
If you will replicate this study on the non-registered language (see this page), you will have to access the English material sheet at first. To translate the materials to your targeted language, the recommended practice is to follow the translation protocol. At this OSF page, we provided the template sheet and target pictures for this study.

articles.title: Materials for replication study
articles.description: Fetch the scripts from the project [OSF](https://osf.io/e428p/).
articles.contents:
Scripts
All the scripts for final data collection turn are available on this OSF page. Check the directories Materials -> js. Download the script you require.
You would extract the materials from OpenSesame GUI. As like the below figure.



(#fig:OS_GUI)File pool browser on the right side show all the picture files. Probe sentences sheet are in the loop on the middle part. Experimenters could edit them directly.



Sentences
In this excel file, we summarized all the English and Chinese sentences for this experiment. When replicators will revise the probe sentences, this excel file help you manage the sheet in the “loop” item. For example, the probe sentences in the above figure were from the “ENG_LIST1” in this excel file.
Pictures
The target pictures are available at this OSF page. Download the zip file and check them in your own device. If you would like the replace the picture, it is recommended to find the pictures as equal size as the original files.

articles.title: General analysis on English data
articles.description: Example analysis on English data from 10 teams.

articles.title: Beyond Replications
articles.description: Brief the analysis plan and the extended analysis.
articles.contents:
Our original plan used mixed-effect model (Baayen, Davidson, and Bates 2008 ; Bates et al. 2015) evaluate the orientation effects and the interaction with languages. Because about 1/3 teams collected data on line, our final analysis plan additionally processed the shift of orientation effects along with the experimental circumstances (in site vs. on line). In this site we reproduced the data analysis based on the partial data. In the sub-pages under this title, we collect the reproducible plans for the researchers who have the interest and resource to conduct the study. A plan managed some extended hypotheses and the simulation-based power analysis. We appreciated mixedpower being the tool to design the study (Kumle, Võ, and Draschkow 2021). We welcome researchers provide your comments and ideas in the site posts.



Baayen, R. Harald, D. J. Davidson, and D. M. Bates. 2008. “Mixed-Effects Modeling with Crossed Random Effects for Subjects and Items.” Journal of Memory and Language 59 (4): 390–412. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jml.2007.12.005.


Bates, Douglas, Reinhold Kliegl, Shravan Vasishth, and Harald Baayen. 2015. “Parsimonious Mixed Models.” 2015. http://arxiv.org/abs/1506.04967.


Kumle, Leah, Melissa L.-H. Võ, and Dejan Draschkow. 2021. “Estimating Power in (Generalized) Linear Mixed Models: An Open Introduction and Tutorial in R.” Behavior Research Methods, May. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-021-01546-0.

articles.title: Orientation effects between the platforms
articles.contents:
In this scenario, we evaluate the match advantage along with the experiment platforms (in site vs. on line). In terms of the coefficients from the real data analysis, we evaluate how many participants and items the reproduction studies will employ. The required numbers of participants and items are based on the simulated-based power analysis. We use mixedpower (Kumle, Võ, and Draschkow, 2021) to compute the reached power. This page followed their notebook to estimate how many participants/items required in the next study. For each simulation the codes estimated powers based on the artificial data and on the smallest effect size of interest(SESOI).
Real data analysis
The data collected from OSWeb appeared to be longer the the data collected from OpenSesame in site. Below mixed-effect model showed a weak match advantage when the platforms(OpenSesame, OSWeb) is treated as fixed effect. We also extract the coefficients for the simulations from the below codes.


EN_OS_model <- lmer(response_time ~ Match*opensesame_codename + (1|Subject) + (1|Target),
                 data = SP_V_en_mutate)

## mixed effect model summary
summary(EN_OS_model)


Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: 
response_time ~ Match * opensesame_codename + (1 | Subject) +  
    (1 | Target)
   Data: SP_V_en_mutate

REML criterion at convergence: 421667.9

Scaled residuals: 
   Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
-0.284 -0.122 -0.043  0.004 85.348 

Random effects:
 Groups   Name        Variance Std.Dev.
 Subject  (Intercept)     2479   49.79 
 Target   (Intercept)    23764  154.16 
 Residual             30302998 5504.82 
Number of obs: 21017, groups:  Subject, 991; Target, 48

Fixed effects:
                                Estimate Std. Error t value
(Intercept)                      651.541     87.368   7.457
MatchY                            -4.069    119.055  -0.034
opensesame_codenameosweb         559.782    109.684   5.104
MatchY:opensesame_codenameosweb   88.170    154.592   0.570

Correlation of Fixed Effects:
            (Intr) MatchY opnss_
MatchY      -0.686              
opnssm_cdnm -0.745  0.546       
MtchY:pnss_  0.528 -0.770 -0.709

## Extract fixed effects
EN_OS_model_fef <- fixef(EN_OS_model)
## Extract random effects
EN_OS_model_ref <- as.list(VarCorr(EN_OS_model) %>% unlist())
EN_OS_model_res <- sigma(EN_OS_model)



The summary showed a weak orientation effect and a huge difference between the study platforms.
Build artificial data
We extracted the required columns from the tidy data. For the accuracy of analysis process, participants’ and targets’ ids were converted to numbers.


## Retrieve the required columns
partial_real_data <- SP_V_en %>% select(PSA_ID, subject_nr, Target, Match, opensesame_codename) %>%
  mutate(Subject = paste0(PSA_ID,"_",subject_nr))

## Build the artifial data
artificial_data <- partial_real_data  %>% 
  mutate(Subject = as.numeric(as.factor(Subject)),
         Target = as.numeric(as.factor(Target)))



In total, we convert the data columns from 991 participants into the artificial data.
Create Lmer
In the mixed-effect model by artificial data, in addition to the residual variance was 1/100 of original coefficient, the other coefficients followed the original result. We adjusted the residual variance in terms of the assumption that the researchers would reproduce this study in a single data collection workflow where the performance variance would be controlled.


# ------------------------------------------ #
# formula for GLMM
formula_lmer <- RT ~ Match*opensesame_codename  + (1 | Subject) + (1 | Target)

# ------------------------------------------ #
# CREATE LMER
artificial_lmer <- makeLmer(RT ~ Match*opensesame_codename  + (1 | Subject) + (1 | Target),
                           fixef = EN_OS_model_fef, VarCorr = EN_OS_model_ref, sigma = EN_OS_model_res/100,   ## Minimze residual std
                           data = artificial_data)

# lets have a look!
summary(artificial_lmer)


Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: 
RT ~ Match * opensesame_codename + (1 | Subject) + (1 | Target)
   Data: artificial_data

REML criterion at convergence: 333640.9

Scaled residuals: 
     Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
-10.1141  -1.7823   0.0032   1.8248  12.6499 

Random effects:
 Groups   Name        Variance Std.Dev.
 Subject  (Intercept)  2479     49.79  
 Target   (Intercept) 23764    154.16  
 Residual              3030     55.05  
Number of obs: 21017, groups:  Subject, 991; Target, 48

Fixed effects:
                                Estimate Std. Error t value
(Intercept)                      651.541     22.398  29.089
MatchY                            -4.069      1.192  -3.412
opensesame_codenameosweb         559.782      3.165 176.881
MatchY:opensesame_codenameosweb   88.170      1.550  56.896

Correlation of Fixed Effects:
            (Intr) MatchY opnss_
MatchY      -0.027              
opnssm_cdnm -0.087  0.190       
MtchY:pnss_  0.021 -0.769 -0.247

The estimated effects were as equal as the real data analysis, but the standard deviations had been smaller.
Power analysis
How many participants we will require?
We decided 5 sample size: 50, 75, 100, 125, 150 and accumulated 1000 simulated results respectively. Because the simulation codes take a lot of time, the below chunk shows the codes only.
model <- artificial_lmer  # which model do we want to simulate power for?
data <- artificial_data # data used to fit the model
fixed_effects <- c("Match", "opensesame_codename") # all fixed effects specified in artificial_glmer
simvar_subj <- "Subject" # which random variable do we want to vary in the simulation?

simvar_item <- "Target"

# ------------------------------------------ #
# SIMULATION PARAMETERS
steps_subj <- c(50,75,100,125,150) # which sample sizes do we want to look at?

steps_item <- c(24,48,72,96,120) # which sample sizes do we want to look at?



critical_value <- 2 # which t/z value do we want to use to test for significance?
n_sim <- 1000 # how many single simulations should be used to estimate power?

# ------------------------------------------ #
# INCLUDE SESOI SIMULATION
SESOI <- EN_OS_model_fef*.15 # specify SESOI (15% smaller betas)

# ------------------------------------------ #
# RUN SIMULATION WITH MIXEDPOWER
power_subj <- mixedpower(model = model, data = data,
                       fixed_effects = fixed_effects,
                       simvar = simvar_subj, steps = steps_subj,
                       critical_value = critical_value, n_sim = n_sim,
                       SESOI = SESOI)
The simulated powers indicated that increasing sample size difficultly improve the power. We could learn very little from a mega study collected thousands of participants.

50

How many items we will require?
We decided 5 sample size: 24,48,72,96,120 and accumulated 1000 simulated results respectively. In the above chunk, we replaced the parameters simvar and steps with simvar_item and steps_item. Because the simulation codes take a lot of time, we finished the simulations before we created this page.

24

The results showed that increasing the items in a study could improve the success rate to detect the orientation effect. On the other hand, when we hypothesize the true effect was smaller than this project measured (see SESOI rows), increasing items help little to detect the orientation effect.
Web report of PSA 002: “Investigating Object Orientation Effects Across 19 Languages”

articles.title: Raw data, tidy data, and Codebook
articles.description: Overview the collected data across languages and laboratory settings.

articles.title: Available data
articles.description: Overview the collected data across languages and laboratory settings.
articles.contents:
Contents
in site data
osweb data
All data

in site data
Between September 2019 and March 2020, the data were collected from the registered teams’ affiliations. All the teams followed the data collection protocol. This data collection suspended at March 2020 because of the global pandemic outbreak.

Chinese","2":"CHN_005","3":"50","4":"50"},{"1":"Simple Chinese","2":"CHN_019","3":"31","4":"30"},{"1":"Slovak","2":"SVK_001","3":"91","4":"91"},{"1":"Slovak","2":"SVK_002","3":"47","4":"47"},{"1":"Spanish","2":"COL_001","3":"69","4":"69"},{"1":"Spanish","2":"ECU_001","3":"58","4":"58"},{"1":"Thai","2":"THA_001","3":"50","4":"50"},{"1":"Traditional Chinese","2":"TWN_001","3":"60","4":"60"},{"1":"Traditional Chinese","2":"TWN_002","3":"33","4":"33"},{"1":"Turkish","2":"TUR_007","3":"84","4":"84"},{"1":"Turkish","2":"TUR_025","3":"99","4":"98"}],"options":{"columns":{"min":{},"max":[10]},"rows":{"min":[10],"max":[10]},"pages":{}}}
  

21 teams completed the data collection or reached the minimal sample size before the global pandemic outbreak. Across the site data, 2014 participants finished sentence-picture verification task; 2007 participants finished picture-picture verification task. Some PP data files were successfully imported after I decreased the criterion of file size. 7 participants’ data files were lost because the experimenters did not upload the files or submitted the wrong files.
osweb data
Between January 2021 and June 2021, the data collection resumed after we migrated the in-site scripts to JATOS website. The rest of teams distributed the corresponding links to their participants.



{"columns":[{"label":["Language"],"name":[1],"type":["chr"],"align":["left"]},{"label":["PSA_ID"],"name":[2],"type":["chr"],"align":["left"]},{"label":["SP_N"],"name":[3],"type":["dbl"],"align":["right"]},{"label":["PP_N"],"name":[4],"type":["dbl"],"align":["right"]}],"data":[{"1":"Arabic","2":"ARE_001","3":"11","4":"11"},{"1":"Arabic","2":"ARE_002","3":"49","4":"49"},{"1":"Brazilian Portuguese","2":"BRA_003","3":"47","4":"47"},{"1":"English","2":"AUS_091","3":"154","4":"154"},{"1":"English","2":"NGA_001","3":"42","4":"42"},{"1":"English","2":"NZL_005","3":"298","4":"298"},{"1":"English","2":"PSA_002","3":"62","4":"62"},{"1":"English","2":"TWN_002E","3":"10","4":"10"},{"1":"English","2":"USA_011","3":"58","4":"58"},{"1":"English","2":"USA_020","3":"24","4":"24"},{"1":"English","2":"USA_030","3":"25","4":"25"},{"1":"English","2":"USA_033","3":"43","4":"43"},{"1":"German","2":"AUT_005","3":"106","4":"106"},{"1":"German","2":"DEU_020","3":"26","4":"26"},{"1":"Norwegian","2":"NOR_002","3":"20","4":"20"},{"1":"Portuguese","2":"POR_001","3":"54","4":"54"},{"1":"Serbian","2":"SRB_002","3":"81","4":"81"},{"1":"Serbian","2":"SRB_002B","3":"45","4":"45"},{"1":"Traditional Chinese","2":"TWN_002","3":"53","4":"53"},{"1":"Turkish","2":"TUR_023","3":"73","4":"73"}],"options":{"columns":{"min":{},"max":[10]},"rows":{"min":[10],"max":[10]},"pages":{}}}
  

The osweb teams collected the data from the languages as following: Arabic, Brazilian Portuguese, English, German, Norwegian, Portuguese, Serbian, Traditional Chinese, Turkish. Across the osweb data, 1281 participants finished sentence-picture verification task; 1281 participants finished picture-picture verification task.
According to our preregistered plan, each laboratory has to collect at least 50 participants. Some laboratories did not reach the minimal criterion because of the following reasons: (1)their works were interrupted by the pandemic situation; (2)the participants performed worse through the online study; (3) the laboratories allocated the seats for the foreign participants; (4) A language (e.g., Serbian) has a various of scripts.
All data



{"columns":[{"label":["Language"],"name":[1],"type":["chr"],"align":["left"]},{"label":["LAB_N"],"name":[2],"type":["int"],"align":["right"]},{"label":["SP_N"],"name":[3],"type":["dbl"],"align":["right"]},{"label":["PP_N"],"name":[4],"type":["dbl"],"align":["right"]}],"data":[{"1":"Arabic","2":"2","3":"60","4":"60"},{"1":"Brazilian Portuguese","2":"1","3":"47","4":"47"},{"1":"English","2":"21","3":"1329","4":"1328"},{"1":"German","2":"3","3":"231","4":"231"},{"1":"Greek","2":"1","3":"98","4":"98"},{"1":"Hebrew","2":"1","3":"146","4":"145"},{"1":"Hindi","2":"1","3":"79","4":"78"},{"1":"Magyar","2":"1","3":"129","4":"129"},{"1":"Norwegian","2":"3","3":"143","4":"141"},{"1":"Polish","2":"1","3":"50","4":"50"},{"1":"Portuguese","2":"1","3":"59","4":"59"},{"1":"Serbian","2":"2","3":"126","4":"126"},{"1":"Simple Chinese","2":"2","3":"81","4":"80"},{"1":"Slovak","2":"2","3":"138","4":"138"},{"1":"Spanish","2":"2","3":"127","4":"127"},{"1":"Thai","2":"1","3":"50","4":"50"},{"1":"Traditional Chinese","2":"2","3":"146","4":"146"},{"1":"Turkish","2":"3","3":"256","4":"255"}],"options":{"columns":{"min":{},"max":[10]},"rows":{"min":[10],"max":[10]},"pages":{}}}
  

At the end of data collection, 50 laboratories participated in this project. 13 laboratories collected the minimal samples. Finally we collected the data from 18 languages.

articles.title: Translation protocol
articles.description: Overview the collected data across languages and laboratory settings.
articles.contents:
The original materials are from the original studies on the orientation effects (Stanfield and Zwaan 2001; Zwaan and Pecher 2012). In addition to the teams recruited the American participants, the other teams had to translated the original materials to the local languages. Translators conducted the translated materials in terms of the PSA protocol.
If you will conduct the translations, you can download the translation template for your work. The target pictures are available at here.



Stanfield, Robert A., and Rolf A. Zwaan. 2001. “The Effect of Implied Orientation Derived from Verbal Context on Picture Recognition.” Psychological Science 12 (2): 153–56. https://doi.org/10.1111/1467-9280.00326.


Zwaan, Rolf A., and Diane Pecher. 2012. “Revisiting Mental Simulation in Language Comprehension: Six Replication Attempts.” PLoS ONE 7: e51382. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0051382.
